title: chilaquiles roja
ingredients: 5 roma tomatoes; split in half, longways
1/2 white onion; cut in half into two large quarters
2 dried chiles de arbol (optional); tops trimmed, deseeded and covered and rehydrated in boiling water for 10 minutes
4 cups tortilla chips (or whatever amount feels right -- I normally grab about four handfuls)
few sprigs of cilantro; roughly chopped
instructions: You can make the salsa roja ahead of time.  Preheat the broiler. Add a tiny bit of oil to a baking sheet -- I find these fit perfectly on the smaller quarter sheet. Add
When ready to cook, preheat a small pan for eggs on medium low and a larger pan on medium high for the tortillas.
Cook the eggs slowly, in a bit of oil, sunny side up or over easy.
While eggs are cooking, add Tbsp of oil to the large pan then add 1 cup of the salsa roja and simmer for a few minutes on its own to develop flavor.  Add broth and bring back up to a simmer
Plate the chilaquiles and add the egg, crumbled feta, chopped parsley and a crack of fresh black pepper.  Serve immediately before it gets soggy.
notes: Meal for two. Based on an Ethan Cheblowski recipe. The salsa is relatively hot, especially if you use the chiles de arbol.
